title: CausalInvestData Explainer
text: CausalInvestData R package provides high-quality, simulated datasets designed developing, testing, teaching causal inference methods context institutional investment management.

title: CausalInvestData Explainer
text: Institutional finance professionals, data scientists, researchers often struggle find relevant datasets training causal models. package solves offering curated, labeled datasets simulate: Fund performance treatment interventions Portfolio allocation strategies Client behavioral outcomes (e.g., churn, satisfaction) Macroeconomic time-series shocks

title: CausalInvestData Explainer
text: Financial data scientists Quant researchers Academics teaching causal inference Developers testing causal ML pipelines

title: CausalInvestData Explainer
text: Propensity score matching investment strategy evaluation Causal forest models treatment heterogeneity Impact advisory services client churn Macroeconomic sensitivity testing

title: CausalInvestData Explainer
text: GitHub: https://github.com/edzai/CausalInvestData (Soon) R-universe: https://edzai.r-universe.dev pkgdown: https://edzai.github.io/CausalInvestData

title: CausalInvestData Explainer
text: Edzai Conilias Zvobwo | edzai@acalytica.com

title: Bayesian Causal Forests
text: Content goes ‚Ä¶

title: Causal Discovery
text: Content goes ‚Ä¶

title: Causal Time-Series Impact Analysis
text: Causal impact analysis estimates intervention affects outcome time. financial settings, might reflect effect policy change, economic shock, strategy shift.

title: Causal Time-Series Impact Analysis
text: ‚Äôll simulate intervention (e.g.¬†policy shock) occurring time point 80.

title: Causal Time-Series Impact Analysis
code: macro_shocks <- macro_shocks %>%   mutate(time = row_number(),          intervention = ifelse(time >= 80, 1, 0))

title: Causal Time-Series Impact Analysis
code: ggplot(macro_shocks, aes(x = date, y = market_index)) geom_line() ## geom_line: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA ## stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE ## position_identity geom_vline(xintercept = macro_shocks$date[80], linetype = "dashed", color = "red") ## mapping: xintercept = ~xintercept  ## geom_vline: na.rm = FALSE ## stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE ## position_identity labs(title = "Market Index with Simulated Intervention at Month 80",        x = "Date", y = "Market Index") ## title: Causal Time-Series Impact Analysis
code: pre_data <- macro_shocks %>% filter(intervention == 0) post_data <- macro_shocks %>% filter(intervention == 1)  model <- lm(market_index ~ interest_rate + gdp_growth, data = pre_data) post_data$predicted <- predict(model, newdata = post_data)  ggplot(post_data, aes(x = date)) geom_line(aes(y = market_index), color = "blue") ## mapping: y = ~market_index  ## geom_line: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA ## stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE ## position_identity geom_line(aes(y = predicted), color = "orange", linetype = "dashed") ## mapping: y = ~predicted  ## geom_line: na.rm = FALSE, orientation = NA ## stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE ## position_identity labs(title = "Observed vs Counterfactual Post-Intervention",        y = "Market Index", x = "Date") ## $y ## [1] "Market Index" ##  ## $x ## [1] "Date" ##  ## $title ## [1] "Observed vs Counterfactual Post-Intervention" ##  ## attr(,"class") ## [1] "labels" theme_minimal() ## List of 136 ##  $ line                            :List of 6 ## title: Data Visuals for Causal Inference
text: vignette demonstrates useful plots commonly used causal analysis diagnostics.

title: Data Visuals for Causal Inference
code: set.seed(123) n <- 500 df <- data.frame(   treatment = factor(rbinom(n, 1, 0.5), labels = c("Control", "Treated")),   age = rnorm(n, mean = 35, sd = 10) )  ggplot(df, aes(x = age, fill = treatment)) +   geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +   labs(title = "Age Distribution by Treatment Group",        x = "Age", y = "Density", fill = "Group") +   theme_minimal()

title: Data Visuals for Causal Inference
code: df <- df %>%   mutate(     income = ifelse(treatment == "Treated", rnorm(n, 60000, 10000), rnorm(n, 50000, 10000))   )  ggplot(df, aes(x = income, fill = treatment)) +   geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +   labs(title = "Income Distribution Before Matching",        x = "Income", y = "Density", fill = "Group") +   theme_minimal()

title: Data Visuals for Causal Inference
code: df <- df %>%   mutate(     outcome = ifelse(treatment == "Treated", income * 0.0009 + rnorm(n), income * 0.0007 + rnorm(n))   )  ggplot(df, aes(x = treatment, y = outcome, fill = treatment)) +   geom_boxplot() +   labs(title = "Outcome by Treatment Group",        x = "Group", y = "Outcome") +   theme_minimal()

title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
text: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects (HTEs) occur impact treatment varies across different units subgroups population. financial decision-making, understanding benefits (less) given strategy can useful knowing average effect. ‚Äôll explore using fund_performance dataset.

title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
text: Let‚Äôs inspect treatment effects differ levels beta (proxy fund risk exposure):

title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
code: fund_performance <- fund_performance %>%   mutate(beta_group = ntile(beta, 3))  # low, medium, high  group_summary <- fund_performance %>%   group_by(beta_group, treatment) %>%   summarise(mean_return = mean(return), .groups = "drop")  group_summary %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(names_from = treatment, values_from = mean_return,                      names_prefix = "treatment_") %>%   mutate(estimated_effect = treatment_1 - treatment_0) ## # A tibble: 3 √ó 4 ##   beta_group treatment_0 treatment_1 estimated_effect ##        <int>       <dbl>       <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1          1      0.0681      0.0801          0.0119  ## 2          2      0.0696      0.0726          0.00305 ## 3          3      0.0791      0.0766         -0.00253

what: üìà Visualize Treatment Effects by Risk Exposure
title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
code: group_summary %>%   ggplot(aes(x = factor(beta_group), y = mean_return, fill = factor(treatment))) geom_col(position = "dodge") ## geom_col: just = 0.5, width = NULL, na.rm = FALSE ## stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE ## position_dodge labs(title = "Returns by Treatment Across Beta Groups",        x = "Beta Quantile Group", y = "Mean Return",        fill = "Treatment") ## $x ## [1] "Beta Quantile Group" ##  ## $y ## [1] "Mean Return" ## title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
text: grf package installed, can run:
code: # Uncomment and install if needed # install.packages("grf")  # library(grf) # X <- fund_performance %>% select(market_return, alpha, beta) # Y <- fund_performance$return # W <- fund_performance$treatment # forest <- causal_forest(X, Y, W) # tau_hat <- predict(forest)$predictions # hist(tau_hat, breaks = 30, main = "Estimated Treatment Effects (GRF)", xlab = "tau_hat")

title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
text: Even without advanced ML, subgroup analysis reveals important insights treatments work differently different fund profiles.

title: Heterogeneous Treatment Effects

R package version 0.1.0, ##   <https://github.com/edzai/CausalInvestData>. ##  ## A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is ##  ##   @Manual{, ##     title = {CausalInvestData: Simulated Datasets for Causal Inference in Investment Management}, ##     author = {Edzai {Conilias Zvobwo}}, ##     year = {2025}, ##     note = {R package version 0.1.0}, ##     url = {https://github.com/edzai/CausalInvestData}, ##   }

title: Instrumental Variables
text: Content goes ‚Ä¶

title: Introduction to CausalInvestData
text: CausalInvestData provides simulated datasets causal inference institutional investment management. package includes four core datasets designed reflect real-world structures, enabling users prototype, teach, evaluate methods propensity score matching, causal forests, impact analysis.

title: Introduction to CausalInvestData
code: library(MatchIt) ## Warning: package 'MatchIt' was built under R version 4.3.3 m.out <- matchit(treatment ~ market_return + alpha + beta, data = fund_performance) summary(m.out) ##  ## Call: ## matchit(formula = treatment ~ market_return + alpha + beta, data = fund_performance) ##  ## Summary of Balance for All Data: ##               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean ## distance             0.4942        0.4919          0.0961     0.9914    0.0250 ## market_return        0.0623        0.0610          0.0134     0.9360    0.0079 ## alpha                0.0102        0.0115         -0.0687     0.9442    0.0194 ## beta                 0.9919        0.9993         -0.0654     0.9965    0.0186 ##               eCDF Max ## distance        0.0725 ## market_return   0.0232 ## alpha           0.0512 ## beta            0.0413 ##  ## Summary of Balance for Matched Data: ##               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean ## distance             0.4942        0.4920          0.0887     1.0413    0.0230 ## market_return        0.0623        0.0602          0.0208     0.9314    0.0088 ## alpha                0.0102        0.0113         -0.0568     0.9830    0.0167 ## beta                 0.9919        0.9992         -0.0650     1.0060    0.0185 ##               eCDF Max Std. Pair Dist. ## distance        0.0730          0.0927 ## market_return   0.0243          1.1393 ## alpha           0.0467          0.8110 ## beta            0.0426          0.8197 ##  ## Sample Sizes: ##           Control Treated ## All           507     493 ## Matched       493     493 ## Unmatched      14       0 ## Discarded       0       0

R package version 0.1.0, ##   <https://github.com/edzai/CausalInvestData>. ##  ## A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is ##  ##   @Manual{, ##     title = {CausalInvestData: Simulated Datasets for Causal Inference in Investment Management}, ##     author = {Edzai {Conilias Zvobwo}}, ##     year = {2025}, ##     note = {R package version 0.1.0}, ##     url = {https://github.com/edzai/CausalInvestData}, ##   }

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
text: Mediation analysis decomposes treatment‚Äôs effect : - Direct Effect: effect treatment mediator - Indirect Effect: effect treatment mediator variable

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
code: set.seed(123) n <- 1000  X <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.5)                # treatment M <- 1.2 * X + rnorm(n)               # mediator Y <- 0.5 * X + 2 * M + rnorm(n)       # outcome influenced by both  df <- data.frame(X, M, Y)

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
code: # Mediator model model_M <- lm(M ~ X, data = df)  # Outcome model including mediator model_Y <- lm(Y ~ X + M, data = df)

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
code: med <- mediate(model_M, model_Y, treat = "X", mediator = "M", boot = TRUE, sims = 500) summary(med) ##  ## Causal Mediation Analysis  ##  ## Nonparametric Bootstrap Confidence Intervals with the Percentile Method ##  ##                Estimate 95% CI Lower 95% CI Upper p-value     ## ACME              2.479        2.231         2.78  <2e-16 *** ## ADE               0.370        0.235         0.50  <2e-16 *** ## Total Effect      2.849        2.579         3.15  <2e-16 *** ## Prop. Mediated    0.870        0.827         0.92  <2e-16 *** ## --- ## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ##  ## Sample Size Used: 1000  ##  ##  ## Simulations: 500

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
code: plot(med)

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
text: ACME: Average causal mediation effect (indirect effect) ADE: Average direct effect Total Effect: ACME + ADE Proportion Mediated: Fraction total effect due mediation

title: Mediation Analysis: Understanding Indirect Effects
text: Imai, Keele, Tingley (2010). general approach causal mediation analysis Pearl (2001). Direct indirect effects
